Of course there's no such as "The best programming language". The languages are like tools, and it's all about choosing the best tool for the job at hand.

Another thing worth mentioning is, the value isn't intrinsically in the tool itself. It also depends on the programmer's experience and the codebase he has access to with this tool. C may be a faster language but if it takes you days to write the program and optimize it, as opposed to a few hours with something like Python, then Python would obviously be the way to go for this specific job.

All of the above comments are 100% Correct, I will just illustrate an example : Let's say the you want to build a dynamic website ( You can do this using most languages, I will just compare between Python & C++)
of-course using C++ is a real pain, but u gain a high performance.. So If you build a small to kinda large Website you won't really care about performance that much that make u use C++ 
Python : Many Ppl Love it, easy to use and can be used in many fields ..
Generally Python is many times slower than C++

So let's pick a live example : Facebook 
Facebook was initially written in PHP (a dynamic slow language compared to C++ ), but when the traffic on facebook was gigantic, They developed HipHop Project : compiler from PHP to c++ (They really Gained a huge boosting to their performance - some bench-marking show the HipHop is faster 6x Php) 

N.B : Facebook has deprecated the HpHpc (The compiler ) & Made a virtual Machine like Java's One for PHP & they also made a new language called Hack ..

Generally Learn More than one Language & try to master one or two of them ...
Advice : learn more than one type of language to get the concepts no more..
Learn C++ or Java or any static Language & old School OOP (Compiled or Run on VM as java )
Learn Python or Ruby : Dynamic, Interpreted 
Learn HTML or XML : to know about the Marking-up Languages (XML really helps to transfer data )
